channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Deploys Missile, Violating Treaty and Challenging Trump
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last week. Russia’s reported deployment of a new type of missile presents another challenge to its relations with the United States.
item.description: Moscow is believed to have two battalions of the ground-based missile, and it has moved forward despite U.S. protests, administration officials say.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Where Is Rex Tillerson? Top Envoy Keeps Head Down and Travels Light
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson boarded his flight to Germany on Wednesday, making his first foreign trip as secretary of state. He has been conspicuously absent from several prominent events, often relying on a surrogate.
item.description: The secretary of state has skipped major events, and he is visiting Germany, his first foreign trip in office, with a bare-bones entourage as hiring for his staff lags.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Ireland’s Prime Minister in Crisis Over Case of Police Whistle-blower
item.media:description: Prime Minister Enda Kenny is facing a political crisis over a police scandal that dates back to 2006.
item.description: The matter of Sgt. Maurice McCabe, who was falsely accused of child sexual abuse, has roiled the highest ranks of the government and been likened to the case of New York City’s Detective Frank Serpico.
item.dc:creator: SINEAD O’SHEA

item.title: Myanmar Says Ex-Army Officer Ordered Prominent Lawyer’s Murder
item.media:description: The funeral last month in Yangon, Myanmar, for U Ko Ni, a well-known human rights lawyer, who was fatally shot at the Yangon International Airport on Jan. 29.
item.description: The Myanmar authorities said the ex-army officer paid another man to kill U Ko Ni, who had been rewriting the Constitution to reduce the power of the military.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE

item.title: India Launches 104 Satellites From a Single Rocket, Ramping Up a Space Race
item.media:description: The Indian Space Research Organization launched a flock of 104 satellites into space over the course of 18 minutes on Wednesday.
item.description: The country nearly tripled the previous record of 37, set by Russia, establishing itself as a major player in the growing market for surveillance and communication.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Trump, Meeting With Netanyahu, Backs Away From Palestinian State
item.description: The president, in talks with Israel’s prime minister, said the U.S. would no longer insist on a two-state solution for a peace accord.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Israeli Settlement Sees Friendly Faces in Trump Administration
item.media:description: Beit El, an Israeli settlement near Ramallah in the West Bank, was founded in 1977 on private Palestinian land originally seized by Israel for military purposes.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: David M. Friedman, President Trump’s nominee as envoy to Israel, has close ties to a religious settlement deep in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In Eastern Mosul, Liberated From ISIS, Battle Rages ‘Day and Night’
item.media:description: An Iraqi special forces counterterrorism service member shooting at an Islamic State drone in a Mosul neighborhood last month.
item.description: In parts of the city, the fight never ended. Residents, struggling to get by without running water and electricity, say they are repeatedly targeted by snipers and grenade-dropping drones.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Facebook Live Killing of Dominican Journalists Leads to Arrest of 3 Men
item.media:description: Investigators at the offices of the FM radio station 103.5 radio station inSan Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic, on Tuesday.
item.description: Gunmen opened fire while one journalist was reading the news at a station east of Santo Domingo. His producer was killed in another room.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Medicine Hat Journal: A Canadian City Thrives on Gas, Like a ‘Wealthy Little Country’
item.media:description: A plant that produces methanol using natural gas on the outskirts of Medicine Hat, in Alberta’s badlands. Medicine Hat is built above the largest and oldest pool of natural gas in Canada.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Medicine Hat, an Alberta city flush with gas wells, oil fields and renewable energy, is setting up a “heritage fund” to secure its future wealth.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

item.title: South Africa, a Nation With Sharp Inequality, Considers a Minimum Wage
item.media:description: Approximately 400,000 people live in Khayelitsha, which is roughly situated between two of South Africa’s richest areas: Cape Town and the wine country of Stellenbosch. The township provides many of the workers for both communities.
item.description: The move would help reduce poverty and inequality, supporters say, but opponents contend it would worsen already high unemployment.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Sayon Town Journal: Living in Darkness, but Holding On to Hope in Liberia
item.media:description: A shop in Sayon Town, where children can buy snacks. A single light bulb there is powered by a generator.
item.media:credit: Jim Tuttle for The New York Times
item.description: Liberians, 13 years after the civil war ended, are still trying to put back together the pieces that the war ripped apart. Electricity is one of those pieces.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Winston Churchill Wrote of Alien Life in a Lost Essay
item.media:description: Winston Churchill, a longtime science enthusiast, at his home in Chartwell, England, in October 1939. He sent an essay to his publisher that month, just weeks after Britain entered World War II, that pondered the existence of extraterrestrials.
item.media:credit: Topical Press Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: At the onset of World War II, he took the time to write a scientific paper about the probability of life elsewhere in the universe.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Palestinians Dismayed as U.S. Appears to Back Off Two-State Solution
item.media:description: A separation barrier near the Shuafat Palestinian refugee camp in East Jerusalem. Some Israelis said a two-state solution to the Middle East conflict is impossible because the Palestinians in the West Bank and those in Gaza disagree on too many issues.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The possible end of a 50-year-old United States policy was raised by a White House official ahead of President Trump’s meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: Defense Secretary Mattis Tells NATO Allies to Spend More, or Else
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, left, and the secretary general of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg, in Brussels on Wednesday. “If your nations do not want to see America moderate its commitment to this alliance, each of your capitals needs to show support for our common defense,” Mr. Mattis said.
item.description: The defense secretary said the United States could “moderate its commitment” to NATO if members did not increase military spending.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Russia Dismisses Reports That Trump Aides Had Contact With Intelligence Agents
item.media:description: The Kremlin’s spokesman, Dmitri S. Peskov, in New York in November. He denied outright that Michael T. Flynn had discussed sanctions with the Russian ambassador to Washington.
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.description: Soon after, President Trump said on Twitter that Crimea had been taken by Russia during the Obama administration, asking if his predecessor had been too soft.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: For North Koreans in Kim Jong-un’s Orbit, Falling From Favor Can Be Deadly
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Ri Yong-ho; Jang Song-thaek; Hyon Yong-chol; Choe Yong-gon; Kim Yong-jin; Kim Won-hong.
item.media:credit: KCNA; Xinhua; KCNA; Pool photo by Jung Yeon-Je; Kyodo News; KCNA
item.description: The list of executions and purges is punctuated with the names of high-ranking officials and confidants of Mr. Kim who later became targets of his displeasure.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Kim Jong-nam, the Hunted Heir to a Dictator Who Met Death in Exile
item.media:description: The forensic department of Kuala Lumpur General Hospital in Malaysia, where the body of Kim Jong-nam was believed to be on Wednesday.
item.description: The half brother of North Korea’s leader, reportedly poisoned in a Malaysian airport, had lived a playboy’s life but never stopped looking over his shoulder.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Runoff Likely in Jakarta Election Seen as Test of Tolerance for Indonesia
item.media:description: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, an ethnic Chinese Christian, campaigning to remain governor of Jakarta, Indonesia, during the first round of voting on Wednesday. A blasphemy trial has him fighting for his political life.
item.description: Gov. Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, an ethnic Chinese Christian who has been charged with blasphemy, appeared to have received the most votes but not enough to win outright.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere: Fighting on Behalf of China’s Women — From the United States
item.media:description: Chinese feminists who took part in the Women’s March on Washington last month. They held signs in Chinese as well as in English in front of the Trump International Hotel.
item.description: Lu Pin, a Chinese feminist who participated in the Women’s March on Washington, talked about opening a new front for China’s women in America.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Venezuela Closes Ranks Around Sanctioned Vice President, Tareck El Aissami
item.media:description: Vice President Tareck El Aissami of Venezuela, left, and President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas in January.
item.description: Venezuela’s president offered a spirited defense of Vice President Tareck El Aissami, who was sanctioned over accusations that he had moved drugs within the country.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)

item.title: Modi Faces ‘Disappointed’ Voters in India’s Most Populous State
item.media:description: A polling station in Meerut, in Uttar Pradesh State. Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is facing a test in elections in the state.
item.description: If the prime minister prevails in Uttar Pradesh, he will gain the political clout he needs to push through his economic agenda. But voters are restless.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: SoftBank of Japan Will Buy U.S. Private Equity Giant Fortress
item.media:description: Masayoshi Son, the founder of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank.
item.description: The surprising acquisition of Fortress Investment Group highlights the immense ambitions of SoftBank’s brash founder, Masayoshi Son.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Dubai Plans a Taxi That Skips the Driver, and the Roads
item.media:description: The Ehang 184 autonomous drone on display this week at the World Government Summit 2017 in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates. The drone can carry one rider and a small suitcase.
item.description: Pilotless drones, capable of carrying one passenger and a small suitcase, are set to begin buzzing above the United Arab Emirates city as early as July.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Trump’s Muted Tone on North Korea Gives Hope for Nuclear Talks
item.media:description: Portraits of the former North Korean leaders Kim Il-sung, left, and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang, the capital, this week. For more than a decade, the United States has publicly refused to engage in direct talks with the country.
item.description: China may see an opening under the Trump administration amid a growing sense in the region that President Barack Obama’s approach failed.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ, CHOE SANG-HUN and MOTOKO RICH

item.title: With Michael Flynn Gone, Russia Sees a Different Trump
item.media:description: President Trump was greeted by Michael T. Flynn, second from left, in Tampa, Fla., this month. Mr. Flynn has since resigned as national security adviser.
item.description: Moscow seems to be cooling to the new president. Some warn darkly that he may be the next target of a Russophobic American establishment.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Trump’s Shift to ‘Outside-In’ Strategy for Mideast Peace Is a Long Shot
item.media:description: A Palestinian boy riding his bicycle near his family’s tent in the southern Gaza Strip. The Hamad City housing complex is in the background.
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.description: A regional approach relying on Arab states has been tried before, and many Palestinians and Israelis are skeptical.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Samsung Heir Again Faces Arrest in South Korea Bribery Scandal
item.media:description: Lee Jae-yong, the leader of Samsung, in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday. A court blocked efforts to arrest him last month.
item.description: Lee Jae-yong’s arrest in a case involving President Park Geun-hye was blocked last month, but, in an unusual move, a prosecutor asked for a second warrant.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Half Brother Is Reported Assassinated in Malaysia
item.media:description: Kim Jong-nam in 2001. He was the eldest son of the deceased North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il and estranged from his half brother, Kim Jong-un.
item.description: The North Korean leader’s estranged half brother, Kim Jong-nam, was said to have been poisoned by two women.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere: In China, a Lonely Valentine’s Day for Millions of Men
item.media:description: A flower market in Beijing on Monday, the day before Valentine’s Day. China’s large gender gap is causing problems for the country’s men, especially poorer, rural ones.
item.description: There are 33.59 million more men than women in China, which makes marriage hard to attain for men, especially those lower on the socioeconomic ladder.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: 7 Hong Kong Police Officers Convicted of Assaulting Protester in 2014
item.media:description: Some of the convicted police officers at District Court in Hong Kong on Tuesday. Six of them face up to three years in prison, and a seventh risks up to four. All were cleared of a more serious charge.
item.description: The beating, caught by a television crew during the pro-democracy demonstrations that swept the city, outraged the public and revived the flagging protests.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Corruption Scandals With Brazilian Roots Cascade Across Latin America
item.media:description: An ice cream vendor waited last month for clients in Lima, Peru, at the base of a replica of Rio de Janeiro’s famous Christ statue, which was defaced with a spray-painted message that reads in Spanish: “Odebrecht, get out of the country.”
item.description: Years of investigations have resulted in 77 Brazilian Odebrecht executives signing plea deals, and now officials across the region are facing legal trouble.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and ANDREA ZARATE

item.title: Mr. Darcy, You’re No Colin Firth
item.media:description: Colin Firth, right, in his turn as Mr. Darcy, and an illustration of what his character may have looked like in the 19th century.
item.description: A study posits that Mr. Darcy, Jane Austen’s character in “Pride and Prejudice,” would have looked “more ballet dancer than beefcake” in the 19th century.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Exit the Dragon: Why China Should Stop Supporting Venezuela
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, right, and President Xi Jinping of China at a welcoming ceremony last month in Beijing.
item.description: Chinese loans are the main lifeline of President Maduro’s government, but it is time for Beijing to let a corrupt regime go.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL LANSBERG-RODRÍGUEZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Theresa May’s Empire of the Mind
item.description: The British prime minister’s vision of Brexit takes place in an imperialist alternate reality.
item.dc:creator: TOM WHYMAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Swearing, Italian Style
item.media:description: Beppe Grillo, leader of Five-Star Movement, speaking at a rally on the Italian constitutional referendum in Turin, Italy, in December.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Marco/ANSA, via Associated Press
item.description: Our language was once an elegant, gentle one. So why are we all cursing like sailors?
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI
